title: The father of the suspected German synagogue killer said his son was a 'loner' who was always in front of his computer
text:
The father of the gunman who allegedly killed two people in Halle, Germany yesterday revealed that his son was a loner and was always on his computer.

In an exclusive interview with BILD, he revealed that his son had no friends and was "never at peace with himself or with the world."

The father also revealed that he couldn't stop arguing with his son: "My opinion never counted. I couldn't get to him anymore."

The suspected attacker was not known to the police as someone with extremist tendencies.

Officially, he also had no registered guns, even though in a video of the crime which he live-streamed on the gaming site Twitch, the gunman claimed he had built his own weapons.

An eyewitness of the attack told BILD that he moved like a soldier and acted purposefully during the attack.

The father of a gunman suspected of killing two people in an anti-Semitic attack at a Synagogue in Halle, Germany Wednesday spoke out and said that his son had no friends and was always in front of his computer.

The father, who was not named, revealed in an exclusive interview with BILD that he couldn't make sense of anything. "We couldn't stop arguing; my opinion never counted. I couldn't get to him anymore."

Read more: Which gun control policies could prevent mass shootings, according to a gun violence expert

Throughout the interview, the father of the gunman — identified as Stephan B [the gunman has not been formally identified by police, but was named by BILD] — shook his head in disbelief: "That he shot someone ..."

He wasn't able to finish his sentence.

He had only last seen his son on Tuesday and described it as any other day.

His parents divorced when he was 14 years old. He was living with his mother in Helbra, a town in Saxony-Anhalt. Halle is just eight and a half miles away from where he lived, so he knew the area very well, the father said.

He graduated from high school, studied chemistry for two semesters, but then had to drop out after a severe stomach operation.

His son was a loner, claimed his father: "He was never at peace with himself or with the world, he was always blaming everyone else."

Read more: The founder of 8chan, the anonymous online messaging board that's a haven for extremist content, calls for the site to be shut down

His father found out that there had been an attack from the news: "I only heard a news flash, something about a synagogue."

When asked whether he immediately thought of his son, the father remained silent.

The suspected shooter had put on a combat outfit and a helmet, shooting at victims near a synagogue and a kebab shop with a submachine gun. He also filmed his attack with a camera on his helmet and streamed the video live on the gaming site Twitch.

In the video, the suspected attacker can be heard insulting himself, calling himself an "incompetent loser" before adding: "I am here and then I will die, the loser that I am." He also expresses his hatred for Jews, saying they were the "guilty ones."

His father also claims the gunman hardly had any friends and often sat in front of his computer. "That boy was always online."

Read more: Trump wants social media companies like Facebook to develop tools for detecting mass shooters before they strike

A neighbor told BILD that he had worked as a radio technician. He was not known to the police as someone with extremist tendencies. Officially, he also had no weapons.

In the video of the crime, the suspected attacker claimed he had built his own weapons. At times, he apologized to the viewers — once because his homemade submachine gun wasn't working.

An eyewitness of the attack told BILD that he moved like a soldier, acted purposefully, and shot quietly. The killer's father said that his son had been with the Bundeswehr (German Armed Forces), but had no special training.
description: In an exclusive interview with BILD, he revealed that his son had no friends and was "never at peace with himself or with the world."
